qas.question: Who first introduced social insurance programs?
What did Bismarck consider social insurance programs to be?
What social reform movements were Protestants working toward in the nineteen century?

answers.text: the abolition of slavery, prison reforms, and woman suffrage

qas.question: What country started programs that led to the welfare state?
What area copied Bismarck's social programs the most?

context: Protestants have founded hospitals, homes for disabled or elderly people, educational institutions, organizations that give aid to developing countries, and other social welfare agencies. In the nineteenth century, throughout the Anglo-American world, numerous dedicated members of all Protestant denominations were active in social reform movements such as <a2_0>the abolition of slavery, prison reforms, and woman suffrage<a2_0/>. As an answer to the "social question" of the nineteenth century, <a3_0>Germany<a3_0/> under <a0_0>Chancellor Otto von Bismarck<a0_0/> introduced insurance programs that led the way to the welfare state (health insurance, accident insurance, disability insurance, old-age pensions). To Bismarck this was "<a1_0>practical Christianity<a1_0/>". These programs, too, were copied by many other nations, particularly in <a4_0>the Western world<a4_0/>.
